docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Kees Waaldijk began surgery shortly before 10 a.m. one recent Saturday in a cement-walled operating room in this city near Nigeria's northern border. More than five hours later, orderlies carried the last of four girls to the recovery ward. In the near-90 degree heat, Dr. Waaldijk's light blue surgical garb had turned dark with sweat. ''We are finished for the day,'' he barked.

headline.main: Nightmare for African Women: Birthing Injury and Little Help

docs.abstract: Obstetric nightmare of fistulas, unknown in West for century, is common lot of young African women, thousands of whom have come to Dr Kees Waaldijk's hospital in Katsina, Nigeria, for surgery; photos; most are teenagers whose babies lodge in narrow birth canals, cutting off blood and ripping holes in bowels and urethras; babies die after horrific labor and girls, some married before menstruation, are left with ripped insides, utterly incontinent and shunned by families and neighbors; UN Population Fund says new cases far outpace repair surgeries and estimates 400,000 to 800,000 women in Nigeria alone suffer untreated; Waaldijk is 64-year-old Dutchman who has operated on 15,000 fistulas in 22 years, riding circuit between Babbar Ruga Hospital and others in rural Nigeria; fistulas are easily prevented by Caesarean section but rural women have no access to such care; issue reflects broader plight of African women, one in 18 of whom die in childbirth in Nigeria, compared with one in 2,400 in Europe; Waaldijk observes that being a woman in Africa 'is truly a terrible thing' (M)
docs.snippet: New cases of fistulas, unknown in the West for nearly 100 years, are far outpacing corrective surgeries.

multimedia.caption: Africa's Obstetric Nightmare

docs.lead_paragraph: The surprise resignation of Lester Crawford as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration was announced late Friday, just as Hurricane Rita threatened the shoreline in Texas, a time calculated to minimize attention. Given that Dr. Crawford, a veteran agency official, had been promoted to the top job only two months ago and had given no hint of wanting to quit, his sudden departure bore all the signs of a forced resignation. His stated reason, that at age 67 it was time to step aside, sounds preposterous. An administration spokeswoman called it a personnel issue. One official cited Dr. Crawford's failure to disclose all financial information before confirmation, a charge his wife, Catherine, denies. Whatever the real reason, Dr. Crawford's departure offers an opportunity for improvement at the embattled agency. Unfortunately, the Bush administration's initial moves are not promising.
docs.snippet: Dr. Lester Crawford's departure from the Food and Drug Administration offers an opportunity for improvement at the embattled agency.

docs.lead_paragraph: Loretha Weisinger tickled the tummy of 1-month-old Kejuan Kelly, then twirled his tiny blue bootie on her finger. She cooed and cradled him, all the while softly lobbing questions at his young mother. How many bottles does he drink in a day? (A lot.) How many diapers? (About five.) Does he have a bowel movement every day? (Yes.) Are you reading him bedtime stories? (Yes, that book you gave me.) Do you turn out the light when you put him down? (Yes, so he knows the difference between day and night.)

headline.main: 'Mothering the Mother' During Childbirth, and After

docs.snippet: Doulas - part mentors, part hand-holders - are increasingly offering their childbirth services to low-income teenagers.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE recent afternoon, three sets of parents, each with early-teenage triplets in tow, arrived at the Old Montefiore Cemetery and filed into the entranceway of a roofless mausoleum, which was lined with shelves of lighted candles and prayer books. Inside is the gravesite of the Lubavitcher grand rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, who died in 1994, leaving no successor. The children waited restlessly in the small courtyard around the rebbe's grave as their parents tore up pieces of paper bearing handwritten prayers and scattered the scraps by the grave. The parents said they had come to the cemetery, in Cambria Heights, Queens, to offer thanks. All had once struggled with infertility until they received a dollar bill and a blessing from the rabbi, who would dispense plenty of both on Sundays at 770 Eastern Parkway, the Lubavitch headquarters in Crown Heights.
docs.snippet: At the gravesite of the Lubavitcher grand rebbe, offerings, prayers and gratitude.

docs.lead_paragraph: Halfway through our move from Philadelphia to Austin, we stopped the van in Tennessee so Regina could have a baby shower. That's a somewhat coy and lame way of saying that she grew up in Nashville and that her mother and best friend still live there. So of course that's where she was showered, not that it made the experience any more fun for me. While I believe that dads should actively participate in every aspect of their children's lives and their partners' pregnancies, there's still something totally absurd about the idea of the ''couple's shower.'' It was Regina who had the ''Baby Bargains'' book. She knew what she wanted and what we needed, and her judgment served as Talmud in our house. My only priority was hanging up a poster of Johnny Cash in the nursery. The shower was held poolside on an oppressively muggy August day in Regina's mother's backyard, which overlooked a golf course. As the bleats of greeting and the pastel-wrapped gift boxes began to accumulate around the pool, Regina's best friend dispatched her husband to fetch some more chairs.

headline.kicker: THE FUNNY PAGES: II. TRUE-LIFE TALES

docs.snippet: Surviving a baby shower the only way he knows how.

docs.lead_paragraph: ANYONE driving by the County Center here on the afternoon of Sept. 12, the day Judge John G. Roberts Jr. began testifying before Congress in Washington, might have seen about a dozen well-dressed women standing at intervals on the sidewalk, each holding a sign bearing a fragment of a message. They were volunteers for Planned Parenthood, and the first woman's sign, in bright pink and blue, read, ''Judge Roberts.'' A little farther down the line, the next read, ''Answer.'' Still farther was: ''The ?'s'' There followed brightly colored signs on choice, safety, privacy and women's health. This Burma Shave-style sign parade -- very little information at a time -- seemed a perfect metaphor for Planned Parenthood's opinion of Judge Roberts's performance at his confirmation hearings for chief justice of the United States. They see his revelations as piecemeal at best, and fear his real opinions on privacy and reproductive issues are antithetical to theirs. By the time those views are fully exposed, they fear, Judge Roberts will be more or less permanently ensconced. He will then have the power to dramatically alter women's lives.

headline.main: Doubts About Roberts, Expressed One Volunteer at a Time
